fields.description:
After spending about 20+ hours of bundling, uploading and registering images sporadically, the ENABLED CLC/Walrus machine's eucalyptus-cloud process can't be stopped:

{code}
[root@viking-01 ~]# service eucalyptus-cloud stop
Stopping Eucalyptus services:

CRITICAL: timed out waiting for eucalyptus-cloud process to shut down (pid=19694, ppid=19693).
CRITICAL: this is most likely a bug; to kill processes (THIS MAY CAUSE DATA LOSS) run: kill -9 19694 19693
done.
{code}

One thing I noticed is that there are files still being held open by Eucalyptus Walrus:

{code}
[root@viking-01 ~]# lsof | grep bukkits
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  466r      REG              147,1 3221225472   26607685 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/again-centos5-cloudinit/d46e6db6-aba6-42b8-a72d-9e833a695b5d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  471r      REG              147,1 3221225472   26607685 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/again-centos5-cloudinit/d46e6db6-aba6-42b8-a72d-9e833a695b5d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  473r      REG              147,1 3221225472   34078788 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v4/7ce1c927-29ca-4e69-bd2a-c01f984c1a8d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  478r      REG              147,1 3221225472   25428036 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v7/a4744474-886b-4347-8410-39fb8536c874
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  479r      REG              147,1 3221225472   26607685 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/again-centos5-cloudinit/d46e6db6-aba6-42b8-a72d-9e833a695b5d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  489r      REG              147,1 3221225472    9568325 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/yet-again-centos5-cloudinit/0d79293a-6e24-48ff-8a97-7576f9557a92
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  493r      REG              147,1 3221225472   25428036 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v7/a4744474-886b-4347-8410-39fb8536c874
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  513r      REG              147,1 3221225472   46268484 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/another-centos5-cloudinit-test/7479bd13-a667-4060-87b4-6d18fbf236e7
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  514r      REG              147,1 3221225472   34078788 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v4/7ce1c927-29ca-4e69-bd2a-c01f984c1a8d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  515r      REG              147,1 3221225472   46268484 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/another-centos5-cloudinit-test/7479bd13-a667-4060-87b4-6d18fbf236e7
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  536r      REG              147,1 3221225472   34078788 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v4/7ce1c927-29ca-4e69-bd2a-c01f984c1a8d
{code}

There is only one instance that is running that is using one of the images in those buckets.  The other instance thats running is using a previously cached image on the NCs.
fields.environment:
*HA*

* 2 x CLC/Walrus
* 1 x SC/CC
* 1 x CC
* 3 x NCs

comments.body:
Attached sosreport from the  ENABLED and DISABLED CLC/Walrus machines.  DISABLED CLC/Walrus doesn't have the eucalyptus-cloud process running at the time of gathering this sosreport.  This was due to the fact that I wanted to recycle the eucalyptus-cloud process on both machines to get rid of the files being held open on the ENABLED CLC/Walrus.

{code}
[root@viking-01 ~]# lsof | grep bukkits
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  466r      REG              147,1 3221225472   26607685 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/again-centos5-cloudinit/d46e6db6-aba6-42b8-a72d-9e833a695b5d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  471r      REG              147,1 3221225472   26607685 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/again-centos5-cloudinit/d46e6db6-aba6-42b8-a72d-9e833a695b5d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  473r      REG              147,1 3221225472   34078788 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v4/7ce1c927-29ca-4e69-bd2a-c01f984c1a8d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  478r      REG              147,1 3221225472   25428036 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v7/a4744474-886b-4347-8410-39fb8536c874
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  479r      REG              147,1 3221225472   26607685 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/again-centos5-cloudinit/d46e6db6-aba6-42b8-a72d-9e833a695b5d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  489r      REG              147,1 3221225472    9568325 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/yet-again-centos5-cloudinit/0d79293a-6e24-48ff-8a97-7576f9557a92
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  493r      REG              147,1 3221225472   25428036 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v7/a4744474-886b-4347-8410-39fb8536c874
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  513r      REG              147,1 3221225472   46268484 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/another-centos5-cloudinit-test/7479bd13-a667-4060-87b4-6d18fbf236e7
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  514r      REG              147,1 3221225472   34078788 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v4/7ce1c927-29ca-4e69-bd2a-c01f984c1a8d
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  515r      REG              147,1 3221225472   46268484 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/another-centos5-cloudinit-test/7479bd13-a667-4060-87b4-6d18fbf236e7
eucalyptu 19694 eucalyptus  536r      REG              147,1 3221225472   34078788 /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/centos5-cloudinit-v4/7ce1c927-29ca-4e69-bd2a-c01f984c1a8d
{code}

The process finally stopped after about 10 minutes.  I was then able to start back up the eucalyptus-cloud process.  Whats odd is that this happened in the first place.  The load on the system was just a bunch of image bundle, upload and registrations (17+ to give some insight).

Version of Eucalyptus being used:

{code}
[root@viking-01 ~]# rpm -qa | grep euca
eucalyptus-release-3.2-1.el6.noarch
eucalyptus-admin-tools-3.3.0-0.1055.el6.noarch
eucalyptus-cloud-3.3.0-0.1055.el6.x86_64
euca2ools-3.0.0-0.17.alpha6.20130516gitf77a2f8.el6.noarch
python-eucadmin-3.3.0-0.1055.el6.noarch
eucalyptus-common-java-libs-3.3.0-0.1055.el6.x86_64
eucalyptus-walrus-3.3.0-0.1055.el6.x86_64
eucalyptus-3.3.0-0.1055.el6.x86_64
eucalyptus-common-java-3.3.0-0.1055.el6.x86_64
{code}
I still haven't been able to reproduce this.  Previously, it was seen after there was a lot of image bundling, uploading and registering.  Still working to reproduce.

The same error was seen on the ECC.  Not sure if its related since its non-HA, but there were issues regarding shutdown and starting the cloud back up.  ECC thread below (reported by [~gregdek]):

{code}
From: Greg DeKoenigsberg <greg.dekoenigsberg@eucalyptus.com>
Subject: [Community Cloud] Fwd: ** PROBLEM Service Alert: communitycloud/DNS Cloud Name is CRITICAL **
Date: June 29, 2013 5:42:34 PM EDT
To: ECC Administrators <ecc-administrator@eucalyptus.com>
Reply-To: ecc-administrator@eucalyptus.com

This was caused by "service eucalyptus-cloud restart" which was
necessary because whatever issue was plaguing the ECC on Friday ended
up preventing all logins today.  Restarted cloud today, now issues of
yesterday seem to be gone: creating of security groups now works.

P.S. the restart did not go cleanly:

[root@community-frontend ~]# service eucalyptus-cloud restart
Stopping Eucalyptus services: CRITICAL: timed out waiting for
eucalyptus-cloud process to shut down (pid=10125, ppid=10124).
CRITICAL: this is most likely a bug; to kill processes (THIS MAY CAUSE
DATA LOSS) run: kill -9 10125 10124
done.
Starting Eucalyptus services:
Eucalyptus services are already running!
[root@community-frontend ~]# kill -9 10125 10124
[root@community-frontend ~]# service eucalyptus-cloud start
Starting Eucalyptus services: done.

The two services in question were eucalyptus-cloud and postgres.

Please ping immediately with any issues you may find.  I have no idea
what data I might have crushed by killing these processes; given that
the cloud is now up and functional, I'm hoping it was simply
noncritical data in transit.

--g


---------- Forwarded message ----------
From:  <nagios@cobbler.localdomain>
Date: Sat, Jun 29, 2013 at 5:31 PM
Subject: ** PROBLEM Service Alert: communitycloud/DNS Cloud Name is CRITICAL **
To: colby.dyess@eucalyptus.com, greg.dekoenigsberg@eucalyptus.com


***** Nagios *****

Notification Type: PROBLEM

Service: DNS Cloud Name
Host: communitycloud
Address: 173.205.188.7
State: CRITICAL

Date/Time: Sat+Jun+29+14:31:55+PDT+2013

Additional Info:

CHECK_NRPE: Socket timeout after 10 seconds.


--
Greg DeKoenigsberg, Eucalyptus
Build your own AWS-compatible cloud in 30 minutes:
http://eucalyptus.com/faststart
{code}
Adding to the sustaining backlog. [~hspencer], please add further information once standing up an HA env.
[~vasya] has seen this in a non-HA environment
A thread dump or steps to reproduce would be required to take any action for this issue (as per EUCA-6195)
[~graziano], [~shaon],please provide the steps to reproduce.
FWIW, I ran into this 2 times in 3.3 hardening. No steps to reproduce. But my case was HA setups.
[~tony] [~hspencer], if possible collect a thread dump when the clc is in a hung state.
I'm hitting this a lot in my development branch. Next time I catch it I'll grab a thread dump.

Here is the startup.log file from a CLC that failed to terminate. Note: I have not done any debugging on this issue.

My setup: 1 CLC/SC/Walrus host. Used for Walrus/RiakCS development, so may have some strange stuff due to that. Also note that this system didn't come up completely normally due a problem in the mule model XML for the object-storage-gateway that I'm working on.

It looks like a bunch of threads are in the TxCleanupService state for cloudwatch metrics, but I've only glanced at the thread dump.
[~kedwards], thread dump attached.
[~zhill], the attached stack looks like  EUCA-6195 (which is proxool related) rather than this issue (though it is possible this issue is a dupe)
Seeing this in 3.4.0 setup. But the thread dump is similar to EUCA-6195 (proxool related). Attaching thread dump again.
[~shaon], I'm not aware of any fix for this issue.
This issue is still happening in 3.4.0. We will close this one once we confirm that this is a duplicate of EUCA-6195.
dup of EUCA-6195
